item.title: Tased and confused: Speedway race ends in chaos
item.description: A crash on a racetrack in the US leads to a brawl between two drivers, with one being tased and arrested in front of spectators.

media:group.media:description: In front of spectators, a police officer fired a taser at Shawn Cullen, leaving him writhing in pain. (Reuters)

item.title: Trump's chief of staff Kelly 'disgusted' his son's death has been politicised
item.description: General John Kelly is reportedly disgusted his son's death in Afghanistan in 2010 has been dragged into a debate initiated by Donald Trump over whether former presidents called the families of slain troops.

media:group.media:description: John Kelly's son was killed in Afghanistan in 2010. (Reuters: Kevin Lamarque)

item.title: Chelsea held to topsy-turvy 3-3 draw by Roma in Champions League
item.description: Chelsea is held to a 3-3 draw by Roma in their Champions League group stage match, in an enthralling contest at Stamford Bridge.

media:group.media:description: Eden Dzeko celebrates levelling the scores against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge. (AP: Tim Goode)

item.title: 'Obviously a fix': Trump says Comey knew he was going to exonerate Clinton
item.description: Donald Trump takes Twitter to revive his long-standing complaint about the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton email server investigation, alleging then-director James Comey protected the Democratic presidential nominee.

media:group.media:description: Donald Trump has again hit out at James Comey over the FBI's Clinton investigation. (AP: Evan Vucci/Reuters: Joshua Roberts)

item.title: 'Russia's Paris Hilton' plans to challenge Putin in 2018 election
item.description: Russian TV personality Ksenia Sobchak announces her plans to run in next year's presidential election, offering an alternative for liberal voters unhappy with Vladimir Putin â€” though she has little prospect of winning.

media:group.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak has been described as Russia's Paris Hilton. (Reuters: Sergei Karpukhin)

item.title: Fact check: Is Myanmar's military free to do what it wants?
item.description: Former Australian prime minister Kevin Rudd says Aung San Suu Kyi is largely powerless to act because of political constraints in a country where the military is supreme.

media:group.media:description: Former prime minister Kevin Rudd says that Myanmar's military has "absolute freedom to do what they wish". (AAP: Dean Lewins)

item.title: US says it holds Myanmar military leaders accountable for Rohingya crisis
item.description: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says the United States holds Myanmar's military leadership responsible for its harsh crackdown on the Rohingya Muslim minority.

media:group.media:description: Mr Tillerson said Myanmar's military had to be disciplined when dealing with militant groups. (Reuters: Yuri Gripas)

item.title: Weinstein resigns from board of his own company amid allegations
item.description: Harvey Weinstein resigns from the board of The Weinstein Company amidst allegations of sexual abuse, whilst retaining ownership of almost a quarter of stock.

media:group.media:description: Harvey Weinstein has been accused of rape, sexual assault and sexual harrassment. (Reuters: Steve Crisp)

item.title: Xi Jinping's speech had something for everyone, but little detail
item.description: In the Chinese President's three-and-a-half-hour address to the nation, he promised to strengthen the military, boost prosperity and reduce disparities in wealth. But there was little detail on how he would do it, writes China correspondent Matthew Carney.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Carney

media:group.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping addresses the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of China in Beijing. (Reuters: Aly Song)

item.title: Why Marawi's 300,000-odd refugees don't blame Islamic State
item.description: As the battle for Marawi appears to be it its final stages and residents begin returning to their flattened homes, the 300,000 people made refugees from the conflict will not be blaming Islamic State for the destruction, writes South-East Asia correspondent Adam Harvey.
item.dc:creator: Adam Harvey

media:group.media:description: Philippine soldiers ride on a military vehicle while government forces continue their assault against insurgents from the Maute group, in Marawi, Philippines June 26, 2017. (Reuters: Jorge Silva)

item.title: China's XI acknowledges economic woes in landmark address
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledges to build a "modern socialist country", while more forcefully addressing the "grim" challenges facing the country, at a twice-a-decade Communist Party Congress.

media:group.media:description: President Xi Jinping outlines his vision for a modern China at the landmark 19th Party Congress. (AP: Mark Schiefelbein)

item.title: PNG's new Speaker to restore 'evil' carvings in Parliament
item.description: Papua New Guinea's new Speaker says priceless carvings that were damaged and removed from Parliament House by his predecessor to cleanse evil spirits will be restored.
item.dc:creator: Liam Fox

media:group.media:description: The carvings were on the front of PNG's Parliament House before they were torn off for being "evil and ungodly". (ABC News: Louie Eroglu)

item.title: Trump says congresswoman 'totally fabricated' comments to soldier's widow
item.description: US President Donald Trump says he has proof he didn't tell a war widow on her way to meet her husband's casket that the soldier "knew what he signed up for".
item.dc:creator: Emily Sakzewski

media:group.media:description: Pregnant widow Myeshia Johnson cries over the casket of husband Sgt La David Johnson, who was killed on duty in Niger. (Supplied: US Defense/AP)

item.title: Ex-hostage rushed to hospital days after rescue
item.description: Former hostage Joshua Boyle says his wife Caitlan has been rushed to the hospital, less than a week after the couple and their three children were rescued from the Taliban-linked Haqqani network in Pakistan.

media:group.media:description: Caitlan Coleman has been rushed to hospital. (AP)

item.title: Another Hollywood exec has resigned following claims of sexual harassment
item.description: The head of Amazon's TV and film studio, Roy Price, resigns following claims he made lewd statements to a female colleague back in 2015. The woman says she came forward in the wake of the Harvey Weinstein revelations.

media:group.media:description: First Harvey Weinstein, now Amazon Studios executive Roy Price has resigned. (Reuters: Kevork Djansezian)

item.title: Boston forward Hayward breaks ankle just minutes into NBA opener
item.description: In a horrific start to the NBA season, Celtics forward Gordon Hayward is stretchered off after suffering a horrible ankle break just minutes into his debut for Boston.

media:group.media:description: Gordon Hayward's broken ankle brought the game to a stand-still and stunned players and fans. (AP: Tony Dejak)

item.title: Carrie Fisher 'personally delivered' cow's tongue to sleazy Hollywood producer
item.description: Late Star Wars actress Carrie Fisher gave a cow's tongue in a Tiffany's box to a sleazy Hollywood producer two weeks after hearing that he forced himself onto a friend, a screenwriter claims.

media:group.media:description: Carrie Fisher "personally delivered" a cow's tongue to a sleazy Hollywood producer, a friend of hers claimed. (ABC Open/Reuters)

item.title: Furyk and Bjorn emulate Palmer, pinging golf balls off the Eiffel Tower
item.description: Jim Furyk and Thomas Bjorn hit synchronised drives from high up the Eiffel Tower in a spectacular countdown to next year's Ryder Cup in France.

media:group.media:description: Thomas Bjorn (L) and Jim Furyk tee off from high up on the Eiffel Tower's viewing platform. (AP: Francois Mori)

item.title: Trump gives warm White House welcome to Greek leader who once called him 'evil'
item.description: US President Donald Trump meets Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in the Rose Garden, where he laughs off the Greek leader's past criticisms and calls him a special man doing special things.
item.dc:creator: Conor Duffy

media:group.media:description: Donald Trump and Alexis Tsipras met in the Rose Garden (AP: Carolyn Kaster)

item.title: Spurs hold Real Madrid at Bernabeu as Liverpool put seven past Maribor
item.description: Tottenham Hotspur battles to a commendable 1-1 draw at the home of reigning European champion Real Madrid, while Liverpool enjoys a thumping 7-0 win on the road.

media:group.media:description: Spurs celebrate their own-goal opener in the 1-1 draw against Real Madrid. (AP: Francisco Seco)

item.title: 'My mother was assassinated': Son of Maltese journalist recalls horror of car bomb scene
item.description: The son of Malta's most famous investigative journalist, who was killed in a car bomb, says he'll never forget seeing the burning wreck of her car and accuses the country's Prime Minister of complicity in her death.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Millar

media:group.media:description: Daphne Caruana Galizia had told police two weeks ago that she was receiving threats. (Reuters: Darrin Zammit Lupi, file)

item.title: After years of bombing and death, Raqqa is free from IS. But the cost of victory is devastating
item.description: There is celebration in the Syrian city of Raqqa, where the Islamic State group has now lost its last stronghold. But behind the cheers is a shattered city where civilians sob in grief, writes correspondent Matt Brown.
item.dc:creator: Matt Brown

media:group.media:description: Raqqa's town square was once the scene of IS military parades but now the ground is littered with debris. (Reuters: Erik De Castro)

item.title: 'Calculated' food shortages starving Rohingya out of Myanmar, rights group says
item.description: A human rights organisation says the Myanmar army is deliberately starving Rohingya Muslims to force them to flee to Bangladesh, with more than half a million having already escaped across the border.
item.dc:creator: Liam Cochrane

media:group.media:description: Food aid has reportedly been cut off to Rohingya villages in Myanmar, forcing residents to flee. (AP: Dar Yasin)

item.title: Prince William and Catherine confirm third child due in April
item.description: The arrival of another Royal baby is officially expected in April next year, with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge saying they are "delighted to confirm" the due date of their third child.

media:group.media:description: The Duchess of Cambridge is back in the public eye again after suffering from acute morning sickness. (Reuters: Jonathan Brady)

item.title: Donald Trump's travel ban thwarted for third time
item.description: A federal judge in Hawaii blocks US President's Donald Trump's third travel ban, just hours before it was due to take effect.

media:group.media:description: A judge found the ban "antithetical to...the founding principles of this nation". (Reuters: Yuri Gripas)

item.title: Spain's top court rules Catalonia's independence referendum illegal
item.description: Spain's top court officially rules that Catalonia's disputed independence referendum was illegal because a regional law that backed it was against the country's constitution.

media:group.media:description: Spain says it will put Catalonia under direct central rule if it does not abandon independence. (Supplied: Brietta Hague)

item.title: Syrian city of Raqqa 'liberated from Islamic State'
item.description: Raqqa is liberated from Islamic State, according to commanders with US-backed forces, ending a four-month battle to take the militants' Syrian capital.

media:group.media:description: Syrian Democratic Forces celebrate the fall of Raqqa. (Reuters: Erik De Castro)

item.title: Murder of Maltese journalist 'an attack on free press and democracy'
item.description: Journalists and writers around the world are outraged at the murder of the woman who has been described as a "one-woman WikiLeaks", warning that her death poses a threat on democracy itself.
item.dc:creator: Anne Barker

media:group.media:description: Daphne Caruana Galizia had told police two weeks ago that she was receiving threats. (Reuters: Darrin Zammit Lupi, file)

item.title: Why the battle over the Iraqi city of Kirkuk matters
item.description: They may be allies in the war against the Islamic State group, but now Iraqi government forces and Kurdish fighters have turned their weapons towards one another.

media:group.media:description: A screenshot from a video showing Iraqi government forces near the headquarters of the North Oil Company and the nearby Baba Gurgur oil field near Kirkuk. (Supplied: Storyful)

item.title: Chinese dreams in a new age of strongman politics
item.description: President Xi Jinping's signature slogan, "The China Dream", is immortalised on billboards, TV ads and on government websites. But the slogan's interpretation depends very much on who you talk to.
item.dc:creator: Bill Birtles

media:group.media:description: A man looks at a building covered in hundreds of posters of President Xi Jinping in Shanghai. (Reuters: Aly Song)

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte declares Marawi 'liberated of terrorist influence'
item.description: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte declares the southern city of Marawi "liberated" from pro-Islamic State militants, despite a military spokesman saying 20 to 30 rebels were still fighting it out and were holding about 20 hostages.

media:group.media:description: Marawi has been devastated by fighting that began on May 23. (Reuters: Jorge Silva)

item.title: Malaysia considers authorising new search for MH370
item.description: Malaysia says it has received proposals from three companies offering to continue the search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which has been missing since 2014, but no decision has yet been made.

media:group.media:description: Extensive searches have failed to locate missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. (Reuters: Andrew Winning, file)

item.title: Australian caught in Bali with drugs had been treated for 'mental disturbance'
item.description: An Australian man accused of bringing drugs into Bali hopes to avoid trial after a local psychiatrist said he was under treatment for mental health problems.
item.dc:creator: Adam Harvey

media:group.media:description: Joshua James Baker was arrested in Bali after marijuana was found in his luggage. (ABC News)

item.title: Who was the 'one-woman WikiLeaks' murdered in a car bombing?
item.description: On October 16, Daphne Caruana Galizia posted her last blog, writing: "There are crooks everywhere you look now. The situation is desperate." Less than an hour later, she was murdered in a car bomb attack. Who was the woman dubbed "Malta's most controversial journalist"?

media:group.media:description: Daphne Caruana Gazalia was described as the "blogging fury" in a 2016 profile. (AP: The Malta Independent)

item.title: Ben Simmons ready at last to take NBA by storm
item.description: After his rookie season was spent on the sidelines, Ben Simmons is finally ready to showcase his prodigious talents when he makes his NBA debut with the Philadelphia 76ers.

media:group.media:description: The time has finally come for Ben Simmons and his 76ers. (AP: Winslow Townson)

item.title: Producers Guild of America moves to expel Harvey Weinstein
item.description: The unprecedented move comes after the board, made up of 20 women and 18 men, agreed to start the expulsion process following widespread sexual harassment claims.

media:group.media:description: The Producers Guild of America is the latest organisation to expel Harvey Weinstein. (AP: Charles Sykes)

item.title: Hostage couple had kids in captivity to 'start dream family'
item.description: Former hostage Joshua Boyle says he and his wife, who were abducted while travelling in Afghanistan five years ago, decided to have children in captivity because they always planned to have a big family and "didn't want to waste time".

media:group.media:description: Joshua Boyle plays with his son in his parents' garden after they return from captivity. (AP: Lars Hagberg)

item.title: Trump branded a 'deranged animal' over claim predecessors didn't honour fallen soldiers
item.description: Donald Trump sparks fury after he says former US presidents didn't properly honour dead and wounded military personnel, with a key staffer of Barack Obama branding the statement a lie.

media:group.media:description: President DonaldÂ TrumpÂ walks from Marine One to board Air Force One, Monday, Oct. 16, 2017, in Andrews Air Force Base, Md., en route Greenville, S.C., for a fundraiser for South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster.Â (AP: Carolyn Kaster)

item.title: 'A political murder': Car bomb kills Maltese journalist who exposed Panama Papers link
item.description: An investigative journalist who exposed Malta's links to offshore tax havens through the leaked Panama Papers is killed in a "barbaric" car bomb so powerful it blows her vehicle into in a nearby field.

media:group.media:description: Daphne Caruana Galizia had told police two weeks ago that she was receiving threats. (Reuters: Darrin Zammit Lupi, file)

item.title: US soldier captured by Taliban for five years pleads guilty to desertion
item.description: Bowe Bergdahl, the US Army Sergeant who was held captive by the Taliban for five years after walking away from his post in Afghanistan in 2009, pleads guilty to charges that could put him behind bars for the rest of his life.

media:group.media:description: Bowe Bergdahl said he never expected to spark such a huge search effort. (AP: The Fayetteville Observer/Andrew Craft)

item.title: China's President poised to take absolute power at party congress
item.description: Having swept aside his rivals, Xi Jinping is set to turn China's most important political event into his coronation. There's growing speculation he'll be named party chairman, a title not given since Mao Zedong.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Carney

media:group.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping has removed rivals with a sweeping anti-corruption campaign. (Reuters: Jason Lee)

item.title: Iraqi forces seize Kirkuk from Kurds after independence vote
item.description: Iraqi Government forces capture the Kurdish-held city of Kirkuk with a bold offensive marking the most decisive action Baghdad has taken to quash the Kurds' bid for independence.

media:group.media:description: Iraqi soldiers on military vehicles in the Qatash area head towardsÂ KirkukÂ gas plant, south ofÂ Kirkuk, Iraq, Monday, October 16, 2017. (APTN via AP)

item.title: Private equity firm in talks to buy Weinstein Co after sexual assault allegations
item.description: The Weinstein Company enters talks to sell the bulk of its assets to private equity firm Colony Capital, as the film production company looks for stability after the removal of disgraced co-founder Harvey Weinstein.

media:group.media:description: A number of women have claimed that Weinstein sexually harassed or assaulted them. (AP: Charles Sykes)

item.title: A new flaw in Wi-Fi affects everyone. Here's how to protect yourself
item.description: A Belgian researcher has turned the tech world upside down by discovering a flaw in Wi-Fi that allows anyone to hack into a connected device. Let's take a look at what you should do to protect yourself.
item.dc:creator: Peter Marsh

media:group.media:description: Any Wi-Fi connected device could be at risk. (Reuters: Keith Bedford)

item.title: Three dead as the worst storm to hit Ireland in 50 years batters the region
item.description: Three people die as Tropical Storm Ophelia batters every corner of Ireland and parts of the United Kingdom, whipping up 10-metre waves, knocking down trees and power lines, and leaving more than 300,000 properties without power.

media:group.media:description: Waves crash over the lighthouse as storm Ophelia passes Porthcawl, Wales. (Reuters: Rebecca Naden)

item.title: What is the #MeToo campaign?
item.description: Have you seen the posts on Facebook and Twitter? Thousands of women are taking to social media to share their stories of sexual harassment using the #MeToo hashtag.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Haynes

media:group.media:description: Actress Alyssa Milano has more than 30,000 responses to her tweet today. (Reuters: Mario Anzuoni)

item.title: Somalia bombing death toll rises above 300 as loved ones search for survivors
item.description: More than 150 unrecognisable bodies have already been buried and Mogadishu locals continue to pack hospitals searching for friends and relatives caught up in Somalia's deadliest attack in a decade.

media:group.media:description: Injured civilians wait to board a Turkish military plane in Mogadishu. (Reuters: Feisal Omar)

item.title: Catalan leader 'didn't give adequate reply' on independence stance
item.description: Spain's Deputy Prime Minister says Catalonia's leader did not give an adequate response in his letter about the region's independence and has until Thursday to comply with the country's laws.

media:group.media:description: Spain's Deputy Prime Minister Soraya Saenz de Santamaria says Carles Puigdemont's response was not adequate. (Reuters: Juan Medina)

item.title: On World Food Day, 350,000 people in Chad face starvation
item.description: What did you eat for breakfast today? How much did you spend on lunch? On World Food Day, spare a thought for some of the hungriest people on Earth.
item.dc:creator: Anne Barker

media:group.media:description: It was hunger that killed Adoum Hassane's (right) 6-year-old son Mohamed. (Supplied: Oxfam)

item.title: Firefighters 'turn a corner' in battle to control deadly California wildfires
item.description: Firefighters gain ground on the deadliest wildfires in Californian history as winds ease and searchers comb charred ruins for more victims of the blazes that have claimed at least 40 lives.

media:group.media:description: Fire officials in California say lighter winds mean they're finally getting the upper hand against the devastating wildfires. (AP: Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.title: Leaders of pro-Islamic State siege of Philippines city 'killed by troops'
item.description: Two leaders of a militant alliance loyal to the Islamic State group are killed in clashes with the armed forces of the Philippines in southern Marawi, the Defence Secretary says.
item.dc:creator: Adam Harvey

media:group.media:description: Abu Sayyaf leader Isnilon Hapilon (pictured) and Omar Maute were killed in clashes with armed forces. (AP: Philippines Military)

item.title: Woody Allen warns against 'witch hunt' after Harvey Weinstein revelations
item.description: Comedian and filmmaker Woody Allen says the Harvey Weinstein controversy is "very sad for everybody involved" but has warned against creating a "witch hunt atmosphere" targeting men in the workplace.

media:group.media:description: Woody Allen said he feels sad for the women involved, and Harvey Weinstein himself. (Reuters: Benoit Tessier)

item.title: 'Every single one of us' must reduce plastic in oceans, says David Attenborough
item.description: Naturalist Sir David Attenborough calls for global action to reduce the amount of plastic in the world's oceans, saying "one species has the future in the palm of its hands".

media:group.media:description: Sir David said "every single one of us" has a responsibility to reduce plastic pollution. (Supplied)

item.title: Ex-Hurricane Ophelia set to lash Irish coast with 110kph winds
item.description: Ireland is preparing for what could be its worst storm in half a century when the remnants of Hurricane Ophelia make landfall on Monday morning (local time), bringing wind gusts of up to 110 kilometres per hour.

media:group.media:description: Hurricane Ophelia approaches the Azores on October 13. (Supplied: NASA)

item.title: Goalkeeper dies after collision with teammate
item.description: A goalkeeper and club legend dies after he races out of his area to smother a loose ball, and collides with a teammate during an Indonesian Super League match.

media:group.media:description: (1 News Express)

item.title: Peruvian pastry chefs earn world record for giant chocolate bar
item.description: Peruvian pastry chefs make the world's largest dark chocolate bar with nuts. The 7-by-3-metre confection has more than 900 kilograms of cocoa, and cost $97,000 to produce.

media:group.media:description: (1 News Express)

item.title: Gavrilova misses out on WTA title in Hong Kong Open final
item.description: Australia's Daria Gavrilova falls short in a rain-hit Hong Kong Tennis Open final, losing to Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova.

media:group.media:description: Daria Gavrilova fell short in pursuit of her maiden WTA title. (AP: Vincent Yu)

item.title: Austria shifts to right as 31yo conservative star seals election win
item.description: Conservative star Sebastian Kurz declares victory as Austria's next leader, but the 31-year-old's party falls short of a majority in Sunday's election and will likely seek a coalition with the resurgent far right.

media:group.media:description: Sebastian Kurz called the triumph "historic" in a speech at his party's celebrations in Vienna. (Reuters: Dominic Ebenbichler)

item.title: Where can North Korea's missiles reach?
item.description: North Korea has threatened Australia with "disaster" â€” but could its missiles reach our shores? And just how much of the world is in potential danger?
item.dc:creator: Matt Martino, Joshua Byrd, Ben Spraggon And Matt Liddy

media:group.media:description: How far can North Korea's missiles reach?

item.title: London police receive new assault claims against Harvey Weinstein
item.description: British police investigate three new allegations of sexual assault against film producer Harvey Weinstein, all made by the same woman.

media:group.media:description: London police said the woman reported being assaulted in 2010, 2011 and 2015. (AP: Chris Pizzello)

item.title: Tillerson says US-North Korea diplomacy will continue until 'first bomb drops'
item.description: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says President Donald Trump has instructed him to continue diplomatic efforts to calm rising tensions with North Korea, saying "those diplomatic efforts will continue until the first bomb drops".

media:group.media:description: Mr Tillerson's comments come amid soaring tensions between the US and North Korea. (Reuters: Yuri Gripas)

item.title: Federer demolishes Nadal to take Shanghai Masters title
item.description: Roger Federer brushes aside world number one Rafael Nadal to win the Shanghai Masters and register his fourth victory of the year over his Spanish rival.

media:group.media:description: Federer is the only player who can take Nadal's number one ranking by year's end. (AP: Andy Wong)

item.title: 276 people killed as 'barbaric' twin blasts rip through Mogadishu
item.description: The death toll from twin blasts in Somalia's capital rises to 276, with another 300 people injured, making it the deadliest attack ever in the Horn of Africa nation.

media:group.media:description: Residents spent hours looking for their loved ones. (AP: Farah Abdi Warsameh)

item.title: Islamic State fighters use human shields as they lose ground in Raqqa
item.description: A final assault is launched on Islamic State militants holding out in Raqqa after a convoy of fighters fled the Syrian city, taking civilians as human shields.

media:group.media:description: A girl cries at a refugee camp in Ain Issa, outside of Raqqa. (Reuters: Erik De Castro)

item.title: Wild elephants trample Rohingya refugees to death
item.description: Wild elephants trample sleeping Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh, killing three children and a woman in the second such incident since the arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees from Myanmar in just a few weeks.

media:group.media:description: In this September 25, 2017 file photo,Â RohingyaÂ Muslim children, who crossed over from Myanmar into Bangladesh, wait to receive handouts near Balukhali refugee camp, Bangladesh. (AP: Dar Yasin, file)

item.title: Trump says he 'met President of Virgin Islands' â€” but that's him
item.description: In a speech about the impact of recent hurricanes, US President Donald Trump says he "met with the President of the Virgin Islands", prompting a correction from the White House over the slip-up.

media:group.media:description: Donald Trump said he "met with with President of the Virgin Islands". (Reuters: Yuri Gripas)

item.title: Family reunites with the dog they thought died in the California fires
item.description: The moment a family dog was found alive and well after its owners thought it perished in California's deadliest-ever fires is captured on video.

media:group.media:description: Jack Weaver, left, and his brother in law, Patrick Widen, pose with Izzy, a 9-year-old Bernese MountainÂ Dog, who belongs to Weaver's parents, Saturday, Oct. 14, 2017, in Windsor, Calif. Weaver and Widen were surprised to discover that Izzy was uninjured in a ferocious wildfire that destroyed the parents' NorthernÂ California neighborhood Monday. Weaver, who was filming the scene for his parents, captured the moment on his phone in a video that's gone viral on Facebook, providing a rare bit of good news amid endless scenes of severe destruction. (AP: Jonathan Copper)

item.title: Long road ahead for India's women after controversial 'triple talaq' divorce law ban
item.description: India's Supreme Court might have ruled that the controversial "triple talaq" divorce law is unconstitutional, but women across the country still face a long and difficult path ahead.

media:group.media:description: Girls from Kashmir, many of whom are keen on going to school and getting jobs. (Supplied: Murali Krishnan)

item.title: Nadal, Federer seal Shanghai Masters showdown as Cilic, Del Potro exit
item.description: The classic tennis rivalry will have one more outing in 2017, as Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer set up a Shanghai Masters finals clash.

media:group.media:description: Roger Federer will face Rafael Nadal for the 38th time on the ATP tour after his win over Juan Martin del Potro. (AP: Andy Wong)

item.title: Twitter is trying to combat harassment â€” again
item.description: CEO Jack Dorsey says Twitter still isn't doing enough and promises more aggressive policing of hate symbols, sexual harassment and unwanted nudity.

media:group.media:description: When Twitter trialled longer tweets, users said it should instead focus on halting harassment. (ABC News: Nic MacBean)

item.title: Manchester City in seventh heaven as rivals flounder
item.description: It's early days in the Premier League season, but Manchester City are looking ominous, racking up seven goals in a thumping win over Stoke as their title rivals stumble.

media:group.media:description: Pep Guardiola's Manchester City side disposed of Stoke with a stunning display at Eastlands. (AP / PA: Mike Egerton)

item.title: Deadliest wildfires in California's history force thousands to flee
item.description: Fast-moving fires force thousands more Californians to evacuate their homes as the death toll from the deadliest blaze recorded in the state's history rises to at least 40, with hundreds of people still missing.

media:group.media:description: Smoke and flame rise from the Hilton Sonoma Wine Country during the Tubbs Fire in Santa Rosa, California, U.S., October 9, 2017. (Reuters: Stephen Lam)

item.title: 'Wilful ignorance is over': Weinstein ousted from film academy in historic move
item.description: The disgraced Hollywood producer is expelled from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in a move the Academy hopes will send a message that "wilful ignorance and shameful complicity in sexually predatory behaviour" in the film industry is over.

media:group.media:description: The expulsion from the academy follows allegations from a number of women that Weinstein sexually harassed them. (AP/Reuters)

item.title: President Xi's hyper-nationalism has people believing in his China Dream
item.description: President Xi is hoping to appoint four out of the seven members of China's top decision-making body, the standing politburo, giving him absolute power to set the direction of China for the next decade.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Carney

media:group.media:description: Chinese PresidentÂ XiÂ JinpingÂ stands on a military jeep as he inspects troops of the People's Liberation Army during a military parade to commemorate the 90th anniversary of the founding of the PLA at Zhurihe training base in north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, Sunday, July 30, 2017. (AP: Li Gang)

item.title: The country that may never be clear of land mines
item.description: Sead Vrana started clearing land mines when he was 17. Now he fears Bosnia's countryside will never be fully cleared of the deadly weapons.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Clayfield

media:group.media:description: Sead Vrana has disabled so many explosives that the number has become "almost meaningless". (Supplied)

item.title: Deal reached allowing civilians, local fighters to flee Raqqa
item.description: In a deal expected to allow the US-led coalition to focus on defeating Islamic State in Raqqa, civilians and local IS fighters, but not foreign militants, will be allowed to leave the IS stronghold.

media:group.media:description: Smoke rises near the stadium where the Islamic State militants are holed up after an air strike by coalition forces at the frontline, in Raqqa, Syria October 12, 2017. (Reuters: Erik De Castro)

item.title: Thomas & Friends to get a jolt of girl power
item.description: Girls are finally getting a bigger role in Thomas the Tank Engine's male-dominated world with the addition of two female main characters, Nia and Rebecca.

media:group.media:description: Nia and Rebecca, to the left and right of Thomas, will be main characters in next year's season. (Mattel via AP)

item.title: Residents flee as IS fighters surrender in Syria's Raqqa

item.title: Japan election campaigns 'a little bit old-fashioned'
item.description: While other countries' election campaigns dominate television and social media, in Japan electioneering methods are a little old fashioned, with strict laws and a reluctance to embrace social media meaning candidates are often seen hitting the streets.

item.title: Former hostage says extremists killed child, raped wife

Boyle, his wife Caitlin Coleman, and their three children landed in Canada after they were kidnapped in Afghanistan while on a backpacking trip and held hostage for five years by the Taliban-linked Haqqani network. (AP: Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press)

item.title: California wildfires rage with record death toll expected to climb

item.title: Flight 666 arrives in HEL for the last time on Friday the 13th

item.title: Las Vegas gunman fired on jet fuel tanks, police, authorities say
item.description: As Steven Paddock's brain is sent away for evaluation, Las Vegas police offer a new timeline of events and describe how the gunman opened fire on nearby airport jet fuel tanks and police officers arriving at the scene of the deadliest shooting in modern US history.

item.title: Trump puts 'dumbest' Iran nuclear deal at serious risk

item.title: How Spain turned the Catalonian fringe issue into a full-blown crisis

item.title: Trump refuses to certify Iran is complying with nuclear deal

item.title: Trump has delivered two blows to Obamacare. Both are likely to do damage
item.description: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order aimed at weakening Obamacare, otherwise known as the Affordable Care Act. Shortly after, he delivered another blow.

item.title: In this town, parents of bullies could face jail time
item.description: In May, a 13-year-old boy was punched by another boy outside a discount shop in a town in New York state. The attack has led to a new law that lets authorities send parents of bullies to jail for up to 15 days and fine them up to $319.

media:group.media:description: Officials say the law aims to encourage parents to actively raise their children (ABC News: Rhiana Whitson)

item.title: Former friend Malaysia halts all imports from North Korea, data shows

item.title: Vietnam floods, landslides leave 54 dead

item.title: Gucci bans fur, will auction remaining merchandise for animal rights charities

For many residents in the path of one of California's deadliest blazes, talk is of wind direction, evacuations and goodbyes. (AP: Jeff Chiu)

item.title: Is this the new normal? Trump threatens the press (again)

item.title: Diplomat robbed at police roadblock in Port Moresby

item.title: The latest trailer for Star Wars: The Last Jedi is here
item.description: We're only two months away from the release of the next Star Wars movie, but if you can't wait for a taste, you're in luck: the latest trailer has dropped.

media:group.media:description: Rey with a lightsaber in the trailer for Star Wars: The Last Jedi (Lucasfilm)

item.title: Police change timeline in deadly Las Vegas shooting
item.description: The Las Vegas gunman opened fire on a security guard six minutes before he rained down bullets on a crowd and killed 58 people, officials say, in a change to the timeline of the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history.

media:group.media:description: Police officers take cover near the scene of a shooting near the Mandalay Bay resort. (AP: John Locher)

item.title: Police officer shot dead at Texas university
item.description: A 19-year-old student accused of fatally shooting a Texas Tech University police officer at the campus police station is in custody.

media:group.media:description: Police at Texas Tech University after the shooting. (AP: Mark Rogers, Lubbock Avalanche-Journal)

item.title: Weinstein reaction: Pitt 'confronted' mogul after Paltrow massage request
item.description: Gwyneth Paltrow has accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual harassment, in an incident which prompted her then-boyfriend Brad Pitt to angrily confront Weinstein at a film premiere. Here's who has spoken out so far.

media:group.media:description: Gwyneth Paltrow says her then boyfriend Brad Pitt confronted Weinstein after he tried to get her to give him a massage. (Supplied)

item.title: NZ Police apologise for using The Office meme in car crash death tweet
item.description: New Zealand Police delete and apologise for a "tone deaf" tweet about road safety using a joke gif of Michael Scott from The Office to convey what it is like for police to notify a family member of a car crash death.

media:group.media:description: Many people expressed disapproval over this meme posted by New Zealand Police â€” but not everyone was critical. (Supplied)

item.title: Malala Yousafzai attends first lecture at Oxford
item.description: Five years since she was shot in the head by the Taliban for speaking in favour of girls' education, Malala Yousafzai attends her first lectures at the University of Oxford.

media:group.media:description: Malala Yousafzai is studying politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford. (Reuters: Ginnette Riquelme)

item.title: Ten dead as wildfires rip through California's wine country
item.description: Wildfires fanned by strong winds roar through Californian wine country, killing at least 10 people, forcing some 20,000 residents to flee and destroying hundreds of homes and businesses.

media:group.media:description: In this photo taken Oct. 8, 2017, firefighters protect a structure off Tubbs lane in Calistoga, California. (AP: Kent Porter/The Press Democrat)

item.title: Turkey urges US to review visa suspension as relations break down
item.description: Tensions between Turkey and the United States sharply escalate after the arrest of a US consulate employee prompts a suspension of visa services and review of security arrangements in Ankara.

media:group.media:description: A woman waits in front of the visa application office as the US Embassy in Ankara. (Reuters: Umit Bektas)

item.title: China's security obsession a point of national pride
item.description: China is the world's ultimate security state â€” Beijing police proudly boast there is no corner of public space that surveillance cameras cannot see.
item.dc:creator: Bill Birtles

media:group.media:description: China's security focus is likely to increase ahead of a major Communist Party meeting in coming weeks. (Reuters)

item.title: 'Hanging from the abyss': Leaders urged to enter Catalonia mediation talks
item.description: Locals fear civil unrest if Catalan President Carles Puigdemont declares independence on Tuesday evening and Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy tries to withdraw autonomy from Catalonia.
item.dc:creator: Steve Cannane

media:group.media:description: Retired journalist Cesar Lopez lobbies for Spain's political leaders to enter formal talks. (ABC News: Tim Stevens)

item.title: Iceland becomes smallest nation to ever reach World Cup
item.description: The darlings of the 2016 European Championships, Iceland becomes the smallest nation in history to qualify for a World Cup with a 2-0 win over Kosovo sending it Russia 2018.

media:group.media:description: Iceland'sÂ fans celebrate after their team scored against Kosovo, during the World Cup Group I qualifying soccer match betweenÂ IcelandÂ and Kosovo in Reykjavik,Â Iceland, Monday Oct. 9, 2017. (AP: Brynjar Gunnarson)

item.title: Google discovers Russian-backed ads placed during US election: reports
item.description: Google finds Russian operatives spent tens of thousands of dollars on ads on its YouTube, Gmail and Google Search products in an effort to meddle in the 2016 US presidential election, a person briefed on the company's probe says.

media:group.media:description: Google says it is taking a "deeper look" at attempts to abuse its systems. (AP: Marcio Jose Sanchez, file)

item.title: The ball is in whose court? Britain, EU clash over stalled Brexit talks
item.description: Britain and its EU partners trade blows over which side should make the next move to unblock Brexit talks, despite concerns a deadline for a divorce deal will be missed and that the UK is heading for a chaotic departure.

media:group.media:description: Theresa May is desperate to regain her authority after her disastrous party speech last week. (AP: Kirsty Wigglesworth)

item.title: Hollywood stars speak out on 'horrifying' Weinstein harassment claims
item.description: A slew of Hollywood stars condemn producer Harvey Weinstein days after accusations of sexual harassment were made public, with three-time Oscar winner Meryl Streep criticising the "inexcusable behaviour" of a man she called "God" in an acceptance speech.

media:group.media:description: Meryl Streep said she did not know about allegations Weinstein had sexually harassed women. (Reuters/AP)

item.title: Bali Governor says he got his numbers wrong on Mt Agung volcano refugees

media:group.media:description: Governor Made Pastika initially said that many of the evacuees were not in real danger. (AP: Firdia Lisnawati)

item.title: Professor who showed people don't spend money rationally awarded Nobel Economics Prize
item.description: An American academic whose research into behavioural economics showed people do not always make rational financial decisions â€” for example, by making big bets at a casino because they think their winning streak will continue â€” is awarded the 2017 Nobel Economics Prize.

media:group.media:description: Richard Thaler said he planned to spend his prize money as irrationally as possible. (AP: Carsten Rehder/dpa, file)

item.title: One story for Trump, another for home: Thailand's junta backflips over elections â€¦ again
item.description: Thai Prime Minister General Prayut Chan-o-cha "clarifies" a joint statement he made with US President Donald Trump that a long-awaited election would be held next year. In short: it won't.
item.dc:creator: Liam Cochrane

media:group.media:description: The Thai PM met with Donald Trump earlier this month. (Reuters: Kevin Lamarque)

item.title: Rare fire devil captured on camera
item.description: A rarely-seen natural phenomenon which appears as a blazing tornado is spotted amid the deadly wildfires tearing through drought-stricken Portugal.

media:group.media:description: (1 News Express)

item.title: In a Uganda slum, chess inspires young players to make their next move
item.description: A chess prodigy whose rags-to-riches story was told in a Disney film inspires a new generation of chess players looking to escape poverty in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Sally Sara

media:group.media:description: Richard Kato, whose life has been transformed by chess, (ABC News: Sally Sara)

item.title: Push to replace Columbus Day with Indigenous Peoples Day gathers momentum
item.description: A movement to recognise indigenous people rather than the man who opened the Americas to European domination gathers steam, but also prompts howls of outrage from some Italian-Americans, who say eliminating their festival of ethnic pride is culturally insensitive, too.

media:group.media:description: More than 30,000 people are expected to march in the Columbus Day parade in New York (AP: Seth Wenig, file)

item.title: Kim Jong-nam murder trial visits lab to examine nerve-agent-tainted clothes
item.description: The Malaysian court, holding the trial of two women accused of killing the estranged half-brother of North Korea's leader, moves temporarily to a high-security laboratory to view the VX-tainted clothes the suspects wore the day of the attack.

media:group.media:description: Siti Aisyah (left), of Indonesia, and Doan Thi Huong, of Vietnam, have pleaded not guilty to killing Kim Jong-nam. (Reuters: Lai Seng Sin)

item.title: EU braces for collapse in Brexit talks as May falters
item.description: Europeans are stepping up quiet preparations for a possible collapse of Brexit talks that could see Britain crash out of the EU without a deal 18 months from now.

media:group.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May's threat of a "no-deal" scenario is unlikely. (Reuters: Stefan Wermuth)

item.title: After Las Vegas shooting, NRA opposes ban on device that turns rifles into automatic weapons
item.description: The bump stock device allows semi-automatic rifles to operate as if they were fully automatic machine guns, and fire hundreds of rounds a minute. They were used by the gunman in the Las Vegas shooting, but the NRA says they shouldn't be banned.

media:group.media:description: A bump fire stock that attaches to an semi-automatic assault rifle to increase the firing rate is seen at Good Guys Gun Shop in Orem, Utah, U.S., October 4, 2017. (Reuters: George Frey)

item.title: Kim Jong-un's sister the rising star of the hermit state
item.description: Having helped build her brother's brand and manage the Korean Workers' Party's propaganda machine, Kim Yo-jong is wielding increasing influence in the rogue nation.
item.dc:creator: Louisa Rebgetz

media:group.media:description: Kim Yo-jong, pictured left, has helped Kim Jong-un portray himself as similar to his popular grandfather. (Supplied)

item.title: Man helps rescue abducted teenager, gives her reward money
item.description: Jasmine Block was abducted by three men and held captive for 29 days before she escaped. A man who helped rescue the 15-year-old has given his $9,000 reward money to her family, saying they need it more than him.

media:group.media:description: Jasmine Block was abducted and held by three men for 29 days before she escaped. (Facebook: Alexandria Police Department)

item.title: Was Scott of the Antarctic sabotaged by his angry deputy?
item.description: Notes unearthed from the British Library suggest Captain Scott's Antarctic expedition may have been fatally undermined by Lieutenant Teddy Evans, who was furious after being sent back to base.

media:group.media:description: Did Teddy Evans sabotage Scott (standing centre) and his party? (National Library of Australia, copyright free)

item.title: Police recount 'deadly game of hide and seek' with Las Vegas gunman
item.description: Officers who raided the hotel room of Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock give a harrowing account of the barricaded door they had to bust through and the booby traps they feared they would find.

media:group.media:description: Police zeroed in on the 32nd floor after Paddock shot at a guard outside his door. (AP: John Locher)

item.title: Is Trump's feud with kneeling football players personal or politics?
item.description: Donald Trump has been quite vocal over the past few weeks about footballers protesting during the national anthem. VP Mike Pence has now walked out of a match over the issue. But why is this issue being given so much attention? Here's what we know about the spat.

media:group.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence stands during the anthem. (Supplied: White House/Myles Cullen)

item.title: Meet Harvey Weinstein â€” the man actors thank in Oscars acceptance speeches more than God
item.description: If you've seen Pulp Fiction, Silver Linings Playbook or the Spy Kids films, you already know more about Harvey Weinstein than you might think. Let's take a closer look at the powerful Hollywood producer and the allegations of sexual harassment that have just seen him fired from the company he co-founded.

media:group.media:description: The explosive allegations were published by the New York Times last week. (Reuters: Danny Moloshok)

item.title: Kurt Fearnley finishes second in Chicago Marathon
item.description: Australian Paralympic great Kurt Fearnley finishes runner-up in the Chicago Marathon's wheelchair category for the second straight year.

item.title: Dove apologises for 'racist' ad showing black woman turning white
item.description: Dove apologises after an advertisement is criticised as "racist" for showing a black woman removing her brown t-shirt and turning into a white woman after using body wash.

item.title: Two white tiger cubs maul zoo worker to death

item.title: Film producer Weinstein fired in wake of sexual abuse allegations

item.title: Trump brags that he invented the word 'fake', dictionary objects
item.description: Donald Trump seems to take credit for coining the word "fake" in his fight against the media, saying it is "one of the greatest of all terms" he has come up with.

media:group.media:description: Donald Trump says "fake" is "one of the greatest terms" he's come up with. (Reuters: Jonathan Ernst)

item.title: Idlib market air strike kills 11 as Turkish forces mass on Syrian border

item.title: 'Absolute joke': Kyrgios unravels after bad call against Nadal

item.title: Vice President Pence walks out of NFL game in protest against protest

item.title: Australia made a human rights promise that's about to be tested

item.title: White House is 'an adult day care centre', Republican senator tells Trump in Twitter spat

item.title: Weakening Hurricane Nate brings burst of flooding, power outages

item.title: UK's Theresa May doubles down amid reshuffle speculation

item.title: More than 300,000 march in Barcelona against Catalonia's independence

item.title: Kim Jong-un promotes his sister to North Korea's inner circle

item.title: Deadly gas explosion sends giant fireball billowing over Ghana's capital
item.description: A deadly explosion rips through a natural gas station in Ghana's capital Accra, sending a giant fireball billowing into the sky and killing at least six people and injuring 35.

media:group.media:description: One person was confirmed dead and several injured after the explosion in Accra. (Storyful/ABC)

item.title: Royal guards killed in attack outside Saudi Arabian palace
item.description: Two members of Saudi Arabia's Royal Guard are dead and more are wounded after a gunman opened fire on them outside a palace in Jeddah.

item.description: Police detain more than 200 opposition activists for taking part in a wave of anti-Kremlin protests across Russia in support of jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

item.description: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani defends his country's nuclear deal with Western powers, which US President Donald Trump is expected to decertify.

item.title: The child bride trade is booming in Myanmar as the gender gap bites in China
item.description: Nandar was offered a job as a hairdresser across the border in China, but when she got there, her grim future became clear.

item.title: Pedestrians injured in collision near London Natural History Museum

item.title: This little girl could help change the lives of other terror attack victims

media:group.media:description: The changes will allow publicly traded companies to obtain a religious exemption. (AP: Alex Brandon)

item.title: Despite 1,000 leads, still no clear motive in Las Vegas shooting
item.description: Police in Las Vegas say they have chased up more than 1,000 leads but still do not know why gunman Stephen Paddock killed more than 50 people and injured nearly 500 more in the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history.

media:group.media:description: Stephen Paddock brought chaos and carnage to Las Vegas as he raked a music festival with rifle fire (AP: John Locher)

item.title: From sky high to rock bottom, the tide turns again for PP Arnold
item.description: It was 1967 and 20-year-old singer PP Arnold had just about everything a young recording artist could want, but she soon went from sky high to rock bottom.
item.dc:creator: Mark Bannerman

media:group.media:description: Fifty years after her initial fame PP Arnold will release unheard music recorded with Barry Gibb and Eric Clapton (Supplied)

item.title: Dogs, cats and civets brought together in Jakarta's fight against rabies
item.description: With their animal instinct, they knew something was coming, as vets emerged with needles to jab dogs, cats and civets in their backsides.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Hawley

media:group.media:description: A vital scheme that has helped ensure the Indonesian capital has remained free of the deadly disease since 2004. (ABC News: Ari Wu)

item.title: Theresa May vows to stay as party plotters attempt to topple her
item.description: British Prime Minister Theresa May vows to stay on as leader, after a former chairman of her Conservative Party announces he has garnered the support of 30 MPs who want her to quit.

media:group.media:description: Theresa May's authority was already diminished by her decision to call a snap election in June. (AP: Yui Mok)

item.title: Madrid official in Catalonia apologises for police violence during vote
item.description: The Spanish Government's official representative in Catalonia apologises for the violent response by Spanish police to protesters who were attempting to vote in a banned independence referendum in the region.

media:group.media:description: Scuffles break out as Spanish Civil Guard officers force their way through a crowd into a polling station. (Reuters: Juan Medina)

item.title: Anti-nuke group founded in Australia wins 2017 Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: An international group that was launched in Melbourne in 2007 to abolish nuclear weapons is honoured for its work to draw attention to the "catastrophic humanitarian consequences" they have when used.

media:group.media:description: The risk of nuclear weapons being used is greater than it has been in a long time, Ms Reiss-Andersen said. (Reuters: The National Archives)

item.title: Why does Donald Trump want to decertify the Iran nuclear deal?
item.description: US President Donald Trump is expected to announce tonight that he will decertify the Iran nuclear deal â€” the landmark pact made in 2015 to curb the country's nuclear program. Here's why he's not a fan.

media:group.media:description: Donald Trump is expected to make a decision soon. (AP/Reuters)

item.title: Why Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock did not fit the mass killer profile
item.description: Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock did not fit the usual profile of a mass murderer. He was not a loner, he had a partner who said she was madly in love with him, and he was a multi-millionaire.

media:group.media:description: Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock killed 59 people, including himself, and injured more than 400. (AP: Eric Paddock)

item.title: No, the NRA hasn't had a change of heart on gun control
item.description: America's most powerful gun lobby says "bump stocks" need tougher regulation. It's a surprising move, but here's why it isn't really about gun control.

media:group.media:description: A bump fire stock that attaches to an semi-automatic assault rifle to increase the firing rate. (Reuters: George Frey)

item.title: Ricciardo insists he'll be with Red Bull in 2018
item.description: Daniel Ricciardo dismisses comments by high-profile Red Bull adviser Helmut Marko which cast doubt on the Australian's future with the Formula One team.

media:group.media:description: There was speculation Red Bull was shopping Daniel Ricciardo around. (Reuters: Francois Lenoir)

item.title: From Puerto Rico to Las Vegas, it was a horrible week for America
item.description: The United States went from one disaster to another this week. North America correspondent Zoe Daniel recaps the tragedies in Puerto Rico and Las Vegas.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Daniel And Brooke Wylie

media:group.media:description: A man is comforted by a friend during a vigil in Las Vegas for victims of the mass shooting. (AP: Gregory Bull)

item.title: Muslim professor shown being dragged off flight claims racial profiling
item.description: A professor who was dragged off a Southwest Airlines flight in Maryland by police after telling the crew she had an allergy to dogs says she was discriminated against because she was "a brown woman with a hoodie".

media:group.media:description: Police remove the woman as passengers wait to depart Baltimore airport. (YouTube: Bill Dumas)

item.title: Iraq missions 'can't compare', says ex-marine who borrowed truck to save Vegas victims
item.description: Knowing there were lives to be saved, former marine Taylor Winston found the keys in a truck and started ferrying dozens of victims to safety. But he knows not everyone he rescued survived.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie March

media:group.media:description: Taylor Winston tells of the moment he decided "alright, we need to do something". (ABC News: Jenny Magee)

item.title: Pro-life Republican representative resigns following abortion pressure allegations
item.description: Republican Tim Murphy, an anti-abortion lawmaker who allegedly urged his mistress to have an abortion when he thought she was pregnant, resigns from US Congress.

media:group.media:description: Tim Murphy had campaigned on a pro-life platform during his time in Congress. (AP: J. Scott Applewhite)

item.title: Former British PM would be questioned over child abuse if he was alive
item.description: Detectives would have questioned former British prime minister Sir Edward Heath over child abuse allegations if he was still alive, police say.

media:group.media:description: Sir Edward Heath, seen here with Richard Nixon at the White House in 1973, was British PM from 1970-74. (AP)

item.title: At least 22 dead as Tropical Storm Nate lashes Central America
item.description: Newly formed Tropical Storm Nate is blamed for at least 22 deaths across Central America as it dumps rain across the region on a path that will carry it towards potential landfall on the US Gulf Coast as a hurricane.

media:group.media:description: Tropical Storm Nate was upgraded from a tropical depression early Thursday, October 5, as it moved from the Caribbean Sea over Nicaragua. (CIRA/RAMMB/NOAA via Storyful)

item.title: Harvey Weinstein taking leave amid sexual harassment allegations
item.description: Oscar-winning movie producer Harvey Weinstein will take a leave of absence from his company and seek therapy after the New York Times reports he is the target of sexual harassment complaints from a number of women over a span of almost three decades.

media:group.media:description: Harvey Weinstein said he will take a leave of absence from his company and seek therapy. (Reuters: Danny Moloshok)
